reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A powerful story with a surprise at the end
reviews.reviewText: She was Chinese, a successful nightclub owner in 1940s Shanghai. He was a Jewish refugee from Germany with a good talent in jazz piano. It was instant attraction. But then under the Japanese occupation began a gradual descent into hell. The lovers made some errors in judgment, but they had their reasons. You should read to find out how it turned out. I highly recommend this book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2024
reviews.reviewText: So much detail. Interesting story and vivid storytelling. A great and educational read. Loved the characters. I wish there was a part 2!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Beautiful and Tragic
reviews.reviewText: The author described so much detail from the dress she wore and the traditional of society. The woman of the time period of this book was explained in detail, it allows the reader to either be appalled or thankful The love between the character s is so real. I would recommend this book to everyone it has twists a d turns on every page.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Interesting setting during WWII, awkward writing and dialogue
reviews.reviewText: Series Info/Source: This is a stand alone book. I got a copy of this book through Amazon First Reads.Thoughts: I enjoyed the unique setting for this book but thought the writing was a bit awkward and the story was just so-so. This book takes place during WWII in Shanghai. It follows a young heiress named Aiyi who owns her own nightclub and a Jewish refugee named Ernest who ends up playing the piano at her club. They end up falling in love but get caught up in all the politics and war of the time.Both Ernest and Aiyi aren't all that likable. Ernest is strangely selfish and doesn't really take his sister's needs into account. Aiyi wants to be successful and is selfish as well. To be fair, to survive in this time it seems like you had to be selfish. I did like that Aiyi was a business owner and tried to stand up for herself as a woman, but she also let a lot of the men in her life force her into bad situations. I didn't really like either of them and felt like their romance was quick and forced. I don't think it helped that the dialogue throughout felt stilted and awkward to me.The story starts in the present and then goes back to the past and then ends in the present. It ends up tying together decently but I found parts, especially in the second half, to be a bit boring and hard to stay engaged in. This feels odd for me to say with all the death and torture going in the background, but we spent a lot of the book just kind of waiting and I struggled to stay interested.I did greatly enjoy the unique historical setting and learning about the events in Shanghai in WWII. I knew that the Japanese had invaded Shanghai but wasn't aware of all the other international pressures in Shanghai at the time. I also had not realized that Shanghai was such a huge refuge for Jews fleeing Europe. I really enjoyed getting a look into the effects of WWII on a region of the world that you don't often get to read about during that time frame.My Summary (3/5): Overall this was okay; I really liked learning about Shanghai and the events that took place there during WWII. I didn't enjoy the awkward writing and dialogue, the unlikable characters, and the winding somewhat pointless plot. While I am happy to have learned more about Shanghai in this historical time, I don't plan on picking up anymore books by this author.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Lots of twists and turns
reviews.reviewText: A great book that has you wondering how it will end with each chapter. Very reminiscent of traditional Chinese tales -- each piece of information seems one way (good\bad) at first, then changes with time.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Another masterful narrative
reviews.reviewText: Once again, Weina Dai Randel weaves a powerful story with exceptional character development into the context of historical events. This story within a story is beautiful, heart-rending and impossible to put down once begun.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Great writer...love the style...so expressive and just displays an excellent use of the English language! There is not a boring page in the book and is my first read by this author

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars A historical fiction romance
reviews.reviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed this book. The going back to the war years before continuing in the present let you see the past of the main character in just his and pieces.I also enjoyed how she realized that she actually did love her cousin/fiancee, even if it wasn't the passionate love she had for Ernest.The fact that several of the characters had regrets that haunted them for years felt very realistic.I enjoyed how the focus was on how war affected the average citizens much more than the soldiers.I would recommend this book.

reviews.reviewTitle: couldn't put down. forgot to eat and don't even remember when I last used the bathroom
reviews.reviewText: i consumed this book within a day . it was hard to put down, and I found myself looking for any chance I had to read it ..on the bus, in a taxi...I even sneaked a few pages in while at the sauna. its now 5am, I've been reading since midnight, and I've got tears streaming down my face ..good book. worth the interruption to your daily life ..

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 13, 2024
reviews.reviewText: The writing flowed as did the story. It was well researched and I felt a connection with the characters so became immersed in their lives. Some writers fail to do that when writing from two POV
Il faut lire ce livre …. Merveilleusement écrit !
Unbelievably i00nteresting and authentic with a slice of history.Who would believe suchsuch incidents really happened in China .Tantalising story of a women with grit and determination.
